questions.question: Which layer is the Earth's outermost layer?

answers.content: Crust
answers.explanation: The crust is the outermost solid layer of the Earth.

answers.content: Mantle
answers.explanation: The mantle lies beneath the crust.

answers.content: Outer core
answers.explanation: The outer core lies beneath the mantle and is liquid.

answers.content: Inner core
answers.explanation: The inner core is at the very center of the Earth.

questions.question: Which layer of the Earth is completely liquid?

answers.content: Crust
answers.explanation: The crust is solid.

answers.content: Mantle
answers.explanation: The mantle is semi-solid rock.

answers.content: Outer core
answers.explanation: The outer core is a hot, liquid layer of molten iron and nickel.

answers.content: Inner core
answers.explanation: The inner core is solid due to immense pressure.

questions.question: Describe the state (solid, liquid or semi-solid) and composition of the mantle.

answers.content: The mantle is semi-solid rock that becomes hotter and more plastic with depth, composed mainly of silicate minerals.
answers.explanation: The mantle behaves like a very slow-moving solid or plastic and is composed of silicate minerals (e.g., olivine, pyroxene).

questions.question: Explain why the inner core remains solid despite having temperatures as high as the surface of the Sun.

answers.content: The inner core remains solid because the immense pressure at Earth’s center prevents the iron and nickel from melting.
answers.explanation: High pressure raises the melting point of materials, keeping the inner core solid even at very high temperatures.

questions.question: Draw a cross-sectional diagram of the Earth and label its four main layers: crust, mantle, outer core, and inner core.

answers.content: Crust labeled correctly
answers.explanation: Student has labeled the outermost layer as 'Crust'. (1 mark)

answers.content: Mantle labeled correctly
answers.explanation: Student has labeled the layer beneath the crust as 'Mantle'. (1 mark)

answers.content: Outer core labeled correctly
answers.explanation: Student has labeled the liquid layer as 'Outer core'. (1 mark)

answers.content: Inner core labeled correctly
answers.explanation: Student has labeled the central solid layer as 'Inner core'. (1 mark)

questions.question: Detailed Teacher’s Plan: “Exploring Earthquakes”

answers.content:
Unit: Forces Shape Earth’s Surface
Year Level: Year 4
Lesson ID: 5887
Lesson Name: Exploring Earthquakes
Duration: 100 minutes
Focus Question: What might cause Earth’s surface to change quickly?
Key Inquiry Question: How do natural forces shape the Earth’s surface?

Lesson Overview:
In this lesson, students investigate how sudden forces—specifically earthquakes—can rapidly alter Earth’s surface. They will: understand plate tectonics, model plate movements using a chocolate bar, analyse the 2024 Noto Peninsula earthquake, and practise writing cause–effect sentences using the conjunction “so.”

Curriculum Outcomes:
• ST2-PQU-01: Poses questions to create fair tests that investigate the effects of energy on living things and physical systems.
• ST2-SCI-01: Uses information to investigate the solar system and the effects of energy on living, physical and geological systems.
• EN2-CWT-02: Uses compound and complex sentences to sequence connected ideas into paragraphs when explaining cause and effect.

Learning Intentions:
Students are learning to:
- Describe how earthquakes can change the landscape.

Success Criteria:
By the end of the lesson, students will:
- Understand that the movement of tectonic plates causes earthquakes.
- Model what happens to the land during an earthquake.
- Use the causal connective “so” to describe the effect of an earthquake on the landscape.

Key Vocabulary (Tier 2 & 3):
- Tectonic plate
- Epicentre
- Landscape
- Causal connective

Background Reading for Teachers:
Earth’s crust is divided into giant, interacting slabs of rock called tectonic plates. These plates move slowly, driven by forces in Earth’s interior. When stress builds at plate boundaries or faults and is suddenly released, shock waves send energy through the crust, producing an earthquake and shaking the ground.

Materials:
- Mini chocolate bars (Mars bar or similar), one per pair
- Plastic knife
- iPad or tablet (for recording slow-motion video)
- Projector or screen for videos
- Printed images (road cracks, tilted house, flooded buildings)
- E-book or article on the Noto Peninsula earthquake (2024)
- Article on Tohoku tsunami (2011)

Assessment Guidance:
• Formative: Observe students’ discussions and quiz responses to check understanding of earthquake causes.
• Informal: Monitor pairs during the model-making activity to assess their ability to describe plate movements and use “so.”
• Checkpoint: Review students’ completed cause–effect table for accurate use of “so” and correct identification of landscape changes.

Lesson Sequence:
1. Introduction (5 min)
   • Display the road-crack image. Ask: “What might cause Earth’s surface to change quickly?” Record ideas. Address misconceptions.

2. Activity 1 – Global Earthquake Animation (5 min)
   • Play “Forces Change Earth’s Surface: 120 Years of Earthquakes” without context. Students describe what they see and hypothesise the map’s meaning. Show three photos of earthquake damage; ask if these inform their hypotheses.

3. Activity 2 – What Causes Earthquakes? (10 min)
   • Explain the animation shows earthquakes from 2000–2021. Define “earthquake.”
   • Watch “What Causes Earthquakes?” video. Complete a four-question multiple-choice quiz on plate movement and Australia’s seismic activity.

4. Activity 3 – Mars Bar Plate Model (15 min)
   • In pairs, model plate convergence using a halved Mars bar. Predict what will happen when halves meet. Gently push halves together; record slow-mo video. Complete the sentence: “The tectonic plates met so Earth’s crust ___.”

5. Activity 4 – Defining Landscape (5 min)
   • Introduce “landscape” (all natural or built features in an area). Students complete a quick interactive labeling local features.

6. Activity 5 – Noto Peninsula Case Study (30 min)
   • Read about the 2024 Noto Peninsula earthquake. Discuss:
     – Which landscape features changed?
     – Which change was worst and why?
   • Introduce causal table: Cause / so / Effect. Complete three rows using examples from the case study.

7. Activity 6 – Tsunami Extension (20 min)
   • Replay the opening earthquake animation; focus on purple flashes. Ask: “What do these flashes show?” Explain tsunamis form when epicentres are offshore.
   • Read the 2011 Tohoku earthquake and tsunami article. Discuss scale of landscape and human damage.

8. Activity 7 – Government Aid Debate (15 min)
   • Present the 2009 Samoa earthquake/tsunami case. Students debate whether Australia’s $10 million aid was justified. Each student must state their position and then articulate an opposing viewpoint.

Differentiation:
• Green Circle (core): Activities 1–5. Essential for meeting learning intentions.
• Blue Square (deeper): Activity 6. Extends understanding to secondary effects (tsunami).
• Black Diamond (challenging): Activity 7. Encourages critical and creative thinking through debate.

Closure (5 min):
• Revisit focus question: “What might cause Earth’s surface to change quickly?” Summarise how plate movements cause rapid change and how we describe effects using “so.”

Homework / Extension:
• Research a local or historical earthquake event. Write three cause–effect sentences using “so.”

questions.question: What is magma?

answers.content: Molten rock beneath the Earth's surface.
answers.explanation: Magma is molten rock stored beneath the surface; it becomes lava when it erupts.

answers.content: Lava that has cooled on the Earth's surface.
answers.explanation: Lava is magma that has reached the surface and cooled.

answers.content: Solid rock fragments ejected during an eruption.
answers.explanation: Those fragments are volcanic ash or pyroclastic material.

questions.question: When magma reaches the Earth's surface, it is called what?

answers.content: Ash
answers.explanation: Ash consists of fine particles of rock and glass produced by eruptions.

answers.content: Lava
answers.explanation: Lava is molten rock once it reaches the surface.

answers.content: Magma chamber
answers.explanation: A magma chamber is the underground pool of magma.

questions.question: Which of the following is an immediate effect of a volcanic eruption on the landscape?

answers.content: Creation of new land from cooled lava
answers.explanation: Lava flows can cool and solidify to form new land.

answers.content: Gradual soil erosion by wind
answers.explanation: Wind erosion is a slow process, not immediate from eruption.

answers.content: Formation of ice caps
answers.explanation: Ice caps form from frozen water, unrelated to eruptions.

questions.question: Describe two ways in which volcanic eruptions can change the Earth's landscape.

answers.content: Volcanic eruptions can cover areas with ash, burying existing landforms, and lava flows can build up new landforms such as volcanic cones and plateaus.
answers.explanation: Ash deposits and lava flows are primary ways eruptions alter landscapes.

questions.question: Explain a knock-on effect of new land formation after a volcanic eruption, using a causal connective (e.g., because, therefore).

answers.content: Because new land formed from cooled lava, fertile soil developed over time, which therefore allowed new plants to grow and animals to repopulate the area.
answers.explanation: Uses causal connective 'because' and 'therefore' to explain the sequence of effects.

questions.question: Draw and label a simple model of a volcanic eruption showing the magma chamber, vent, and lava flow, and illustrate how the landscape changes before and after the eruption.

answers.content: Expected drawing includes: a cross-section showing a magma chamber beneath the surface, a central vent, arrows indicating rising magma, and surface flows labeled lava. Before-and-after panels showing original landscape and new landforms built by cooled lava.
answers.explanation: The drawing correctly labels key parts and shows landscape change.

questions.question: What does the term 'weathering' describe?

answers.content: The breaking down of rocks into smaller pieces by natural forces.
answers.explanation: Weathering is the process that breaks down rocks over time.

answers.content: The movement of rock particles by water or wind.
answers.explanation: That describes erosion, not weathering.

answers.content: The melting of ice into water.
answers.explanation: This describes a change of state, not weathering.

answers.content: The formation of clouds in the atmosphere.
answers.explanation: This is a meteorological process, not weathering.

questions.question: Which of these is NOT considered an agent of weathering?

answers.content: Wind
answers.explanation: Wind is an agent of weathering.

answers.content: Water
answers.explanation: Water is an agent of weathering.

answers.content: Plants
answers.explanation: Plant roots can break rocks and cause weathering.

answers.content: Gravity
answers.explanation: Gravity alone moves material (erosion) but is not classified as a direct agent of weathering.

questions.question: Explain how moving water causes weathering of rocks.

answers.content: Moving water carries sand and small particles that collide with rock surfaces, wearing them down by abrasion over time.

questions.question: Describe one example of biological weathering caused by plants.

answers.content: Plant roots grow into cracks in rocks. As the roots expand, they pry the rock apart and cause pieces to break off.

questions.question: Draw and label a simple diagram showing how wind weathers rocks.

answers.content: A sketch of rock surfaces being hit by airborne sand particles with arrows indicating wind direction, labels for 'wind', 'sand particles', and 'abraded rock surface'.
answers.explanation: The diagram shows wind carrying particles that strike and wear away rock surfaces.

questions.question: What best describes erosion?

answers.content: The breaking of rocks into smaller pieces
answers.explanation: This describes weathering, not erosion.

answers.content: The movement of rocks, soil and sand to another place
answers.explanation: Erosion is defined as the movement of rock fragments from one location to another.

answers.content: The dropping or settling of rock fragments
answers.explanation: This describes deposition, which follows erosion.

answers.content: The chemical change of minerals in rocks
answers.explanation: This describes chemical weathering, not erosion.

questions.question: Explain why a steeper slope causes more erosion in the moving water experiment.

answers.content: A steeper slope makes water flow faster, increasing its force and ability to carry more sand away.
answers.explanation: Faster-moving water exerts greater force on particles, leading to increased erosion.

questions.question: Draw and label the three tray setups (flat, gentle slope, steep slope) and show where most sand was moved. Include arrows for water flow and indicate sand displacement.

answers.content: A diagram showing three trays: flat tray with little sand at bottom, gentle slope with moderate sand displacement, steep slope with large sand pile at end. Arrows indicate increasing water speed down steeper trays.
answers.explanation: The drawing correctly shows the relative erosion in each setup with labeled trays and displacement.

questions.question: In the erosion investigation, what was the independent variable?

answers.content: The amount of water poured
answers.explanation: The water amount remained the same each trial.

answers.content: The slope of the tray
answers.explanation: The slope was the one factor that was changed between trials.

answers.content: The type of sand used
answers.explanation: The sand type was kept constant to ensure a fair test.

answers.content: The time taken to pour the water
answers.explanation: The pouring time was kept consistent to focus on slope effects.

questions.question: Name two factors that were kept the same in each tray to ensure a fair test.

answers.content: The amount of water poured and the type of sand used
answers.explanation: Keeping water volume and sand type constant controls other variables besides slope.

questions.question: Write a conclusion to answer: Does the force of water cause more erosion when it flows down a steeper slope? Provide evidence from the experiment.

answers.content: Yes. The tray with the steepest slope showed the most sand displacement because the water flowed fastest there. The flat tray had the least erosion, and the gentle slope was intermediate. This shows that greater slope (and thus greater water force) increases erosion.
answers.explanation: This conclusion correctly answers the question and cites experimental evidence comparing the three slopes.
